body: so docker issue? :)

I'm prepared to believe that, but it's just strange that it's happening now and never before. I changed nothing about the image except the caravel version:

https://github.com/amancevice/superset/compare/0.14.1...master
does mapping the ports to 8088:8088 in the superset 0.15.0 container change anything?

No, no change in behavior:

```bash
$ docker run -d --name superset-0-15-0 -p 8088:8088 amancevice/superset:0.15.0
$ curl http://localhost:8088/health
curl: (52) Empty reply from server
$ docker exec superset-0-15-0 curl http://localhost:8088/health
OK
```
I also tried building a new image from scratch using the debian distribution (current is alpine), but same behavior there, too.

This one line PR here https://github.com/airbnb/superset/pull/1827 fixes the problem you are describing (stack trace). I also fixes the fact that we shouldn't send the data synchronously on the explore view load.

Please fix the landscape/codeclimate issues. A new example `Slice` in `superset/data/__init__.py` would be nice to showcase this feature with an example and would automatically get picked up for backend tests and provide coverage.

I did not dig deep into the derivative class of `BaseViz` but it seemed like there was some copy-paste from other NVD3 timeseries classes. If there's lots of common logic it should be handled in a parent class, but that may be complex and obfuscating. I could take a deeper look if necessary.

Excellent. This is neat.

Somehow I got `AUTH_REMOTE_USER` to work by doing something more complicated. I derived the class and overrode, method and passed it to the security manager. Your approach is easier and this hook can be used for any arbitrary middleware which is great.

@kingo55 I'm in sync with @bkyryliuk on this. Would happily review a PR that added a hook for Google Analytics and the likes.

I've also been meaning to ship our internal "Superset Usage" dashboard along with the codebase examples so that people can analyze how Superset is doing in their environment.
@bkyryliuk I think this one is for you since you have all the context here

Running in debug mode seems to fix it:

```bash
$ docker run -d --name superset-0-15-0 -p 8088:8088 amancevice/superset:0.15.0 runserver -d
$ curl localhost:8088/health
OK
```

I suspect this commit to be the culprit: https://github.com/airbnb/superset/commit/50da4f8c0708f91ff24c0abd7189a137a1415bf6

Ah, I think this is it: https://github.com/airbnb/superset/blob/master/superset/bin/superset#L46

The default address is `0.0.0.0` for debug mode, but `127.0.0.1` for normal.

Confirmed that this works:

```bash
$ docker run -d --name superset-0-15-0 -p 8088:8088 amancevice/superset:0.15.0 runserver -a 0.0.0.0
$ curl localhost:8088/health
OK
```

I'll open a PR
this generally LGTM. there are a lot of code changes here, would probably be beneficial to write some tests as well, but could come in another PR if you want to get this out asap.
thx for this @mistercrunch. lgtm. looks like you may need to rebase master to get a passing build.

Thanks for the quick response (and the awesome software)!

To get `AUTH_REMOTE_USER` working, I also had to do some additional configuration. But now everything can be done from `superset_config.py`:

```python
# superset_config.py

SUPERSET_AUTH_TYPE = os.getenv("AUTH_TYPE", "AUTH_REMOTE_USER")

if SUPERSET_AUTH_TYPE == "AUTH_REMOTE_USER":
    from flask_appbuilder.security.sqla.manager import SecurityManager
    from flask_appbuilder.security.sqla.models import User
    from flask_appbuilder.security.manager import UserRemoteUserModelView
    from flask_appbuilder.security.manager import AUTH_REMOTE_USER

    class RemoteUserSecurityManager(SecurityManager):
        user_model = User
        userdbmodelview = UserRemoteUserModelView

    class RemoteUserMiddleware(object):
        def __init__(self, app):
            self.app = app
        def __call__(self, environ, start_response):
            user = environ.pop('HTTP_X_PROXY_REMOTE_USER', None)
            environ['REMOTE_USER'] = user
            return self.app(environ, start_response)

    AUTH_TYPE = AUTH_REMOTE_USER
    CUSTOM_SECURITY_MANAGER = RemoteUserSecurityManager
    ADDITIONAL_MIDDLEWARE += [RemoteUserMiddleware, ]
```

I don't think making the default less secure is a good idea, i don't like to have to remember to change the ip address when running superset from my laptop on a network i don't trust.

~~@amancevice what's your use case? Is it for development or production?~~

UPDATE: found this is a response to the docker issue
And for some reason i cannot find looking at the code we're binding to 0.0.0.0 by default since a few.

Something like the following untested hunk should do the trick:

```
diff --git a/superset/models.py b/superset/models.py
index 10928ff..dde86bf 100644
--- a/superset/models.py
+++ b/superset/models.py
@@ -2520,7 +2520,7 @@ class Query(Model):
         DateTime, default=datetime.utcnow, onupdate=datetime.utcnow, nullable=True)
 
     database = relationship(
-        'Database', foreign_keys=[database_id], backref='queries')
+        'Database', foreign_keys=[database_id], backref=backref('queries', cascade='all, delete-orphan'))
     user = relationship(
         'User',
         backref=backref('queries', cascade='all, delete-orphan'),
```
I'm breaking this down into a dozen or so PRs, keeping open while the process is ongoing for reference.

In the end it turned out render() and resize() has to be called after mounting, otherwise the slice will refer the old ref instead of newly mounted ones.
I reverted the original query appraoch, added the views column to dashboards and slices, pre populated them with Log data in the migration file.

Shouldn't autocomplete simply use the case already being used by the user
rather than force one way or another? I never use upper case for SQL
keywords but I know I'd be frustrated if I did and the tool insisted on
lower case. Don't "fix" the problem by breaking it for other people is my
main concern.

I am getting the same error and I have python 3.5 and also the link provided here is not worth as their is another link in it to install which is not working. please help

i believe it is a requirement to choose a database before running your query even if you have just pasted a query into the sql editor pane. the sql query should determine the schema and table but does not specify the database afaik, which is why it needs to be choosen from the dropdown.

another option here is to always choose a default db so if the user pastes a query into the editor they will be able to run the query right away. if it's against the wrong db, they should get a useful error message.

digging into this a little bit. looks like on first slice click from a dashboard, it loads the correct slice, and for every other slice click after that it loads the same slice as the first one. still digging into the cause.

The one who knows if your machine / database / network is slow or under stress it's you. I don't think we can help there.

Thanks for the PR, I would have left the tests untouched and added a single test to check that the middleware is working. Otherwise we are not testing that our urls are stable. Please wait for @mistercrunch and @bkyryliuk opinions before updating the PR.

I'm open ot the idea of doing this.

Though what about the hard coded urls on the `.js` side?

We should also add tests around the FAB urls.

And to @xrmx's point, we need to make sure that all current URLs are unchanged as users have bookmarks.

Awesome. I have [recently obtained] merge priviledges on the FAB repo if we need to change anything on that side.

I'm assuming your end goal is to add a prefix (subfolder) in the URL for the whole site for reverse-proxying, so where in the configuration would you set this prefix? I was looking for a `URL_PREFIX` element in `config.py` as part of your PR but didn't see it.

Cool with the FAB merge powers. I might have a more thorough look for hard coded urls there as well then.

I'd go for not adding a `URL_PREFIX` setting. Although a nice shortcut for people, I'd say it's good to get them to think about what they are doing. Especially since getting it working not only requires setting up Flask correctly, but also the proxy server.

It's [fairly straight forward to setup the proxying](http://flask.pocoo.org/snippets/35/), so I think it should be left as an exercise to the reader, with good hints in the documentation of course.
Another option would be to add the needed prefix at build time through webpack.
Are you using 0.15.0 or master?

We also need a dynamic prefix/subdir for our usecase. We want to do multi-tenancy on the path so we need one instance of superset to be able to serve many different paths. It's still possible if the prefix is added on build time, but a lot more painful.

To not derail this much further, I think I should compile my JS changes and do another PR and we can discuss it there.

On topic: is it fine to change the tests to hardcode `/test/...` for the urls? If so, I can do that and update the PR.
Does it work if you don't specify the schema?
